titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edward Robb Ellis Papers MSS.068
titlestmt.author: Processed by Tania Friedel and Jessica Shimmin, June 2003

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from ellis.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-20 17:07:27 -0400.

did.abstract: The bulk of the collection is a continuous diary kept from 1927 up until Edward Robb Ellis' death in 1998. The diary includes handwritten and typed entries as well as photographs and correspondence and consists of bound volumes and loose pages. Also included in the collection are clippings arranged into subject files, book typescripts and audio and visual media.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Papers donated by Edward Robb Ellis in 1993.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Edward Robb Ellis Papers; MSS 68; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Edward Robb Ellis was born in 1911 in Kewanee, Illinois. He began writing his diary in 1927 and continued writing until his death in 1998. Determined to be a reporter, Edward Ellis attended the journalism program at the University of Missouri and in 1934 took his first job as a professional reporter for the New Orleans Associated Press office. In this position he covered the events of the Great Depression and the political career of Huey Long. After two years in New Orleans, he moved to Oklahoma City and became a journalist for the Oklahoma City Times covering New Deal offices and programs. As part of this position he reported on the Oklahoma Federal Symphony Orchestry, which was funded by the Works Progress Administration. Through this assignment Eddie met and fell in love with the principal violinist, Leatha Sparlin. They married in 1939 and moved to Peoria, Illinois where he worked for the Journal-Transcript. The couple then moved to Chicago where Eddie worked for The Daily News. Their daughter Sandra Gail Ellis was born on December 28, 1942.

Shortly after Sandra's birth, Eddie Ellis became aware that a previous diagnosis of a hernia was incorrect. He anticipated being drafted and consequently sought a commission in the navy. He was unable to receive one due to his low weight. As a result, he joined the navy and reported to training on November 7, 1942. Because diary keeping was prohibited in the armed forced he changed the format of the diary from private entries to letters to his wife and daughter. Ellis detested boot camp, upon finishing he was appointed editor of the navy hospital newspaper called The Bedside Examiner. He used his position to publish editorials promoting enlisted people's rights as well as critiques of war. After basic training he was stationed in Okinawa where he continued to publish a newspaper, this time explicitly to improve the sailors' morale. Four months later the war ended and he returned to the United States. His wife requested a divorce, which he granted the following month and returned to work at The Daily News in Chicago.

Ellis did not fit in under the new management at the newspaper in Chicago however, and he soon left for New York to work at the World Telegram. Ellis loved New York City deeply and would remain in the City for the rest of his life. There he met and married Ruth Kraus. They had an exceptionally happy marriage. After 15 years at the World Telegram Ellis quit after a disagreement with a city editor. He used his time unemployed to write several books, often with Ruth's help. He published four A Diary of the Century, Epic of New York, Echoes of Distant Thunder, and A Nation in Torment.

Ruth died suddently of a heart attack in 1965. Eddie Ellis went on to have several extended romances, one with June Morgan and another with Selma Pezaro. Although Eddie was not a strong presence in his daughter's childhood, he and Sandy became close in her adulthood, writing numerous letters and challenging each other intellectually. He also forged mentoring relationships with other diarists, usually as a result of interviews and through the publication of parts of the diary in A Diary of the Century. His reputation as a diarist led Letts of London to create a diary modeled on his recommendations called "The Ellis Diary".

Edward Robb Ellis died in 1998 of emphysema. Throughout his career as a reporter, Eddie Ellis interviewed numerous political and cultural celebrities including Eleanor Roosevelt, Irving Berlin, Grace Kelley and Herbert Hoover. The diary records his impressions of these famous personalities. Ellis was equally fascinated by the experiences and perceptions of ordinary people. He prided himself on his curiosity and eagerness to learn and considered himself what Shakespeare called "a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles." The diary is a collection of those trifles and Eddie Ellis's attempt, as Pete Hamill writes in the introduction to A Diary of the Century "to freeze time" and reflect on himself and humanity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of a continuous diary spanning over sixty years. The diary includes written and typed entries as well as personal correspondence, photographs, magnetic audiotape, Super 8 home movies as well as video and audiocassettes. Also included in the diary are book typescripts, subject files and scrapbooks of newspaper clippings covering a wide range of topics. All materials except media are described to the box-level only.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I: Diary The diary contains bound volumes of handwritten and typed entries as well as loose entries, newspaper clippings, photographs and correspondence. The diary is arranged chronologically by year with larger documents in four oversize boxes.

Series II: Subject Files Subject files contain newspaper and magazine clippings grouped by Edward Ellis and organized alphabetically with larger items located in five oversize boxes. Two very large items are located in the map case.

Series III: Book Typescripts Series three contains manuscripts for completed and partially completed books including fiction and non-fiction works. Typescripts are arranged alphabetically by title. This series also includes one oversize box.

Series IV: Media This series contains magnetic audiotapes and cassettes of interviews and correspondence as well as mounted color transparencies, videocassettes and 8mm double film. Media is arranged chronologically with undated materials at the end of the sequence. Access copies are not yet available for this material.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: A box level inventory was created.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary contains bound volumes of handwritten and typed entries as well as loose entries, newspaper clippings, photographs and correspondence. The diary is arranged chronologically by year with larger documents in four oversize boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subject files contain newspaper and magazine clipping grouped by Edward Ellis and organized alphabetically by first letter with larger items located in five oversize boxes. Two very large items are located in the map case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series three contains manuscripts for completed and partially completed books including fiction and non-fiction works. Typescripts are arranged alphabetically by title. This series also includes one oversize box.

did.unittitle: Diary of a Reporter and Diary of a Century
Diary of a Century, Echoes of a Distant Thunder, The Ellis Diary and Epic of New York
Epic of New York, Erika, Harbor of New York, A Nation in Torment, The Old Man Turns On, A Sexual History of the United States, and Steve
Steve, Traitor Within, The Watchdogs, and Miscellaneous Manuscripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains magnetic audiotapes and audiocassettes of interviews and correspondence as well as mounted color transparencies, videocassettes and 8mm double film. This series is arranged chronologically with undated materials at the end of the sequence.
